file_content.text: Leave me in peace.
Have you done it? Have you purified the river?
The purification station was driving violent monsters from the river and into nearby villages.
No, I broke the valve.
Your plan was madness. It was murder.
No, you're insane.
You've been listening to the settlers--listening to those Hutt lies.
I was about to put the purification chemicals into the water when the valve broke. I think it was rusted.
[Lie] There was an accident.
That's not possible. Clearly you broke the valve on purpose. You've been speaking to the settlers--listening to Hutt lies.
The Hutts pay those settlers to live by the river so everyone will think the river's safe.
And then the settlers work in the industrial zone and dump more dangerous chemicals into the river. Nasty, vicious cycle and they deserve what they get.
That's an awfully cruel thing to say.
That's harsh.
That doesn't justify anything.
No sense arguing. It's too late now.
Maybe.
Of course I'm right. But it's too late now.
Story of my life, really. If I'd realized when I was younger what the Hutts were doing, I could've finished the purification myself.
Too late. Too late. Please, just leave me in peace.
Goodbye.
I think our business is concluded.
I'm done here.
I'm stunned that you can be at peace with what you've done.
I don't know how you live.
Yeah, yeah. Goodbye. Meddling fool.
You've done it, yes? You've purified the river?
Pollution is no longer a problem, but those monsters are.
Cleaned up one mess at least.
What are you going to do? You don't like angry monsters coming out of the river? Don't live near the river.
That's what I say.
I'll take my money.
As promised, the few credits I have, and something else for you--a map to some special items hidden in the industrial zone. Enjoy, and thank you.
It was nothing.
Still, I appreciate it.
It was worth it just to hear the settlers scream.
I enjoyed it.
Everyone gets what's coming to them. That's the way the world works.
I'm out of here.
Goodbye.
I never dreamed cleaning up the environment could involve so much beautiful bloodshed.
Oh, the carnage!
Yes, well, you have to do what you have to do. If the settlers want to live by that poisonous soup and suck up to the Hutts, they can.
But they'll get what's coming to them.
Seems a little harsh.
Some people have underdeveloped survival instincts.
No kidding.
Knew you'd see things my way.
Anyway--here's your reward. It's a map that leads to some useful things I hid in the industrial zone in my younger days.
You're sick.
You say so. But try looking at life hooked up to artificial lungs. It looks different.
Anyway, sorry about your conscience, but thanks for the help. Here's the reward I promised--a map to some special items hidden in the industrial zone.
I'm sure you'll make good use of it.
Thanks.
I just wish I didn't feel so uneasy about the whole thing.
This leaves a sour taste.
Eh, relax. You did the right thing.
Nice talking to you, old man. See you later.
Goodbye.
Goodbye, and I hope you come to a better end than I have.
Please, cleanse the river!
Excuse me--yeah, over here--I know, I sound strange. You don't have to say it.
I need a droid's voicebox to help me speak now. Funny, I spent all my life working among machines, and now I can't live, can't speak without 'em.
Why can't you speak on your own?
I don't understand.
That's so sad.
I'm not looking for pity.
You expect me to start crying, old man?
You looking for pity?
That would be a waste of tears, I think.
Forty years I worked in the factories by the river, breathing the noxious poisons they produced. Made a fair number of credits.
But now my lungs're useless. Spine's bent from hard labor. I can't do anything for myself. I gotta ask for help from someone strong, like you.
What do you need?
I'm no doctor, but I'm sure the medical staff here are doing their best.
Not sure how helpful I'll be.
It's not a doctor I need--it's muscle. But brains wouldn't hurt either.
I'm not in the business of charity, old man. Why should I help you?
Why should I care?
Well then--because I can pay for services rendered, I suppose.
Before the effects of Hutta's pollution made me an invalid, I set up a pollution treatment system to clean the river.
Every extra credit I had went into maintaining that system--until the settlers on the river drove me out.
Weren't the settlers grateful for your help?
Why did they do that?
People are disgusting.
It's the vile Hutts! They bought off the settlers and spread lies about my work--all to preserve their precious industry.
That industry is the cause of all of Hutta's problems! The filth, the poison--comes from their pipes and smokestacks!
Your environmental concerns aren't my problem.
I couldn't care less.
Just hear me out, please.
If the Hutts hadn't paid off the settlers in the area to drive me away, the river would be pure again.
The river needed only one more treatment to be free of their vile filth! All I'm asking is that you take the last treatment to the river.
Of course I'll take the last treatment.
Sure.
Excellent. Thank you.
This canister contains the purifying chemicals. The filtration system's up at the Old Muckworks. Good luck.
I have no time for this.
No thanks. [Refuse quest]
Time? You're young! I am out of time--and Hutta will be, too, if someone doesn't act.
I hope you reconsider.
What a miserable life I've led.
